abstract.p: The management of pulmonary nodules involves self-management. This study, conducted in China between September and October 2022, explored the knowledge, attitude, and practice (KAP) towards pulmonary nodules among Chinese adults. The participants were enrolled through convenience sampling when they visited the hospital. The KAP questionnaire was developed by the investigators. Participants who received scores of ≥ 75% of the total score for each dimension were defined as good or positive, 50–75% as moderate, and ≤ 50% as poor or negative. A total of 1209 participants, with an average age of 38.7 years, completed a self-administered online questionnaire. The knowledge, attitude, and practice scores were 5.95 ± 3.54/12, 29.05 ± 4.04/40, and 23.72 ± 6.08/45, respectively, indicating poor knowledge, moderate attitude, and moderate practice regarding pulmonary nodules. The multivariable analyses showed significant associations among knowledge, attitudes, and practice. The mediation analysis indicated that knowledge, education, income, smoking habits, and awareness of pulmonary nodules influenced participants’ practices. In conclusion, a significant population of adults in China had inadequate knowledge, attitude, and practice towards pulmonary nodules. Sufficient knowledge was associated with appropriate practices toward pulmonary nodules. Therefore, health education programs aimed at improving knowledge about pulmonary nodules may be helpful for encouraging appropriate attitudes and maintaining healthy practices.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Lung cancer was the first cause of cancer worldwide in 2022 (estimated 2,480,301 new cases, or 12.4% of all cancers) and the first cause of cancer-related death (1,817,172 deaths, or 18.7% of all cancer-related deaths)1. Lung cancer is also the leading cause of cancer death in China, ranking first and second in males and females, respectively2. Due to the lack of typical symptoms in the early stages of lung cancer, many patients are diagnosed in the middle to late stages, resulting in a low survival rate of 5 years for most lung cancer patients in China3. With the application and popularity of low-dose computed tomography (LDCT), lung lesions are being progressively detected, especially pulmonary nodules, which can improve the detection rate and reduce the mortality rate due to lung cancer4. However, it has been reported that the proportion of pulmonary nodules found in the general population with malignant pulmonary nodules is only 4%, and the proportion of pulmonary nodules found through physical examination in incidental or non-high-risk populations is relatively lower5. The high false-positive rate of pulmonary nodules may have adverse effects, such as increasing the psychological stress of the patient, leading to unnecessary further examinations (e.g., positron emission tomography), or even invasive procedures such as surgery or puncture6. Therefore, it is crucial to properly understand and manage pulmonary nodules after detection.

According to knowledge, attitude, and practice (KAP) theory, people’s practices towards disease control are usually influenced by their knowledge and attitudes related to the disease7–9. Knowledge is the foundation for appropriate attitudes and developing healthy practices, while attitudes are the motivation for adhering to healthy practices. Therefore, improving knowledge and attitudes level toward pulmonary nodules can promote standardized follow-up and effective intervention practices. According to surveys, a number of individuals with indeterminate pulmonary nodules, whether found incidentally or through lung cancer screening, experience significant pain and reduced health-related quality of life10,11. Additionally, several studies have evaluated the degree to which some patients are affected by pulmonary nodules in the United States12,13. It has been demonstrated that the distress of some patients might have been related to insufficient knowledge and evaluation of pulmonary nodules14. However, little is known about knowledge and attitudes, nor is there evidence regarding the factors that influence practices towards pulmonary nodules among Chinese adults.

In order to facilitate proper understanding and management of pulmonary nodules in China, this study investigated the KAP toward pulmonary nodules among Chinese adults. It was hypothesized that Chinese adults have a limited KAP toward pulmonary nodules.

sec.title: Study design and participants
sec.p: An online cross-sectional study was conducted between September 6 and October 8, 2022, in China. The inclusion criteria for participation were (1) Chinese nationality, (2) 16 years old or above, (3) understood and completed questionnaires independently, and (4) volunteered to participate in the study. Incomplete and/or invalid questionnaires were excluded.

The research was carried out in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki. This study was ethically approved by the Medical Ethics Committee of the First Affiliated Hospital of Jinzhou Medical University (#202258), and oral informed consent was obtained from all participants. In China, individuals aged 16–18 years have the right to consent to medical procedures and non-interventional research without parental consent.

sec.title: Procedures
sec.p: A self-administered questionnaire was developed based on NCCN Clinical Practice Guidelines in Oncology (NCCN Guidelines) for lung cancer screening15, Guidelines for Management of Incidental Pulmonary Nodules Detected on CT Images: From the Fleischner Society 201716, and Chinese expert consensus on the diagnosis and treatment of pulmonary nodules17. The questionnaire was reviewed by three experts and then modified according to their suggestions. The final questionnaire consisted of four dimensions: (1) Basic information section, consisting of 10 items; (2) Knowledge dimension, consisting of 12 questions, with 1 point for correct answers and 0 points for incorrect or unclear answers, ranging from 0 to 12 points; (3) Attitude dimension, consisting of eight questions using 5-point Likert scale, ranging from very positive (5 points) to very negative (1 point) according to the degree of positivity, with a score range of 8 points to 40 points.; (4) Practice dimension, comprised of nine questions, also using a 5-point Likert scale, judged based on whether a behavior is positive or not, ranging from “Always” (5 points) to “Never” (1 point), with a score range of 9–45 points. Higher scores for knowledge, attitude, and practice represent better knowledge, positive attitude, and proper practices of the participants. Participants who received scores of 75% and above of the total score for each dimension were defined as good or positive, 50–75% as moderate, and ≤50% as poor or negative.
The questionnaire shows acceptable internal consistency and adequate sampling size with Cronbach’s alpha (α = 0.7752) and KMO = 0.833018.

sec.title: Questionnaire distribution
sec.p: The final questionnaire was in Chinese and shared using the Wen-Juan-Xing online platform (https://www.wjx.cn/app/survey.aspx). The potential participants were approached by a study team member at the convenience of the patient and the study team (convenience sampling) when the patient visited the hospital. The eligible individuals participated in the study and completed the questionnaire by clicking the link they received on WeChat from the study team or by scanning the quick response (QR) code provided by the study team. All questions were compulsory, and the completeness, consistency, and validity of all the questionnaires were checked by study team members.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: The outcome was the KAP dimension scores and levels of the participants. Stata 17.0 (Stata Corporation, College Station, TX, USA) and SPSS 26.0 (IBM Corp., Armonk, N.Y., USA) were used for statistical analyses. The continuous data were tested for normal distribution using the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test. All continuous variables were found to be normally distributed. Continuous data were expressed as means ± standard deviations (SD), and group comparison was analyzed using ANOVA. Categorical data were expressed as n (%). Pearson’s correlation was used to analyze the correlation between knowledge, attitude, and practice scores. Correlation between KAP dimensions was interpreted as follows: weak correlation = 0.10 to 0.39, moderate correlation = 0.40 to 0.69, strong correlation = 0.70 to 0.89, and very strong correlation = 0.90 to 1.0019. Univariable and multivariable logistic regression analyses were used to analyze the factors influencing practice. 70% of the practice score was used as the cutoff value. Mediation analysis was used to estimate causality among KAP dimensions and various factors20–22. Using two-sided tests, differences with P < 0.05 were considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Demographic characteristics
sec.p: A total of 1209 participants were enrolled, including 503 (41.60%) males and 706 (58.60%) females, with an average age of 38.7 years. Among them, 975 (80.65%) were noncity residents, and the monthly income of 725 (59.97%) was less than RMB 5,000, reflecting a relatively low level of economic and social development. The total scores of knowledge, attitude, and practice were 5.95 ± 3.54/12, 29.05 ± 4.04/40, and 23.72 ± 6.08/45, respectively. The lower knowledge scores were found in the participants who were male (P < 0.001), city residents (P = 0.001), high school/technical secondary school and below (P < 0.001), unemployed (P = 0.012), with less than RMB 2,000 monthly income (P < 0.001), previously smoked (P < 0.001), without medical insurance (P < 0.039), and no pulmonary nodules (P < 0.001). Moreover, attitude scores significantly differed across gender (P = 0.002), age (P = 0.008), education level (P = 0.002), monthly income level (P = 0.009), marital status (P = 0.002), and smoking habit status (P = 0.009). As for practice scores, the lower scores were observed among participants who were older than 40 years old (P = 0.004), high school/technical secondary school and below (P < 0.001), and another marital status (e.g., divorced) (P = 0.011) (Table 1).

sec.title: Knowledge, attitude, and practice dimensions
sec.p: The correctness rates of answers for the 12 questions on the knowledge of pulmonary nodules were 26.96–79.57%. The three lowest-scoring questions were about the cause of pulmonary nodules, the period of diagnosis and prognosis of pulmonary cancer, and the need for antibiotics for densely calcified nodules (Table 2). The attitudes of the participants towards pulmonary nodules are presented in Supplementary Fig. 1. More than 70% of the participants believed (very positively or positively) that pulmonary nodules were very common and benign with no need to be worried or followed up. Nearly 45% of the participants were worried (very positively or positively) about CT radiation during screening or follow-up, while only about 34% of the participants were anxious (very positively or positively) about the detection of pulmonary nodules. More than 70% of the participants believed that pulmonary nodules were likely to be inflammatory and that antibiotic treatment was effective. Only about half of the participants were willing to (very positively or positively) accept PET-CT examination or surgery if recommended by the doctors. Moreover, approximately 80% of the participants would (very positively or positively) consider quitting if smoking was a risk factor for pulmonary nodules.

sec.p: Less than 40% of the participants always or often took care to avoid risk factors, such as smoking, air pollution, etc. Nearly 60% of the participants never proactively screened for pulmonary nodules. When pulmonary nodule screening was positive, about 60% of the participants would (always or often) consider regular follow-up reviews. However, only less than 20% of the participants would consider taking antibiotics, puncture biopsy, and surgical resection (Supplementary Fig. 2). Differences exist between total knowledge score (P < 0.001), total attitude score (P < 0.001), total practice score (P < 0.001), preventive behaviors in life (P1.1–P1.4) (P = 0.002), patient compliance for screening and treatments (P3.1–P3.4) (P < 0.001), regular follow-up review (P3.1) (P < 0.001), taking antibiotics (P3.2) (P = 0.003), puncture biopsy (P3.3) (P = 0.002), and surgical resection (P3.4) (P < 0.001) for those who are screening not proactively versus those who are screening proactively (Table 3).

sec.title: Pearson correlation analysis
sec.p: Pearson correlation analysis showed a weak and positive correlation between knowledge scores and attitude scores (r = 0.218, P < 0.001) and knowledge scores and practice scores (r = 0.215, P < 0.001). However, no correlation was found between attitude scores and practice scores (P > 0.05) (Table 4).

sec.title: Univariable and multivariable logistic regression analysis
sec.p: Univariable logistic regression analysis showed that knowledge scores (OR = 1.085, 95% confidence interval (CI): 1.046–1.126, P < 0.001), age > 40 (vs. age ≤ 30, OR = 0.542, 95% confidence interval (CI): 0.392–0.751, P < 0.001), junior college/university (vs. high school/technical secondary school and below, OR = 1.395, 95% confidence interval (CI): 1.027–1.894, P = 0.033), master’s degree and above (vs. high school/technical secondary school and below, OR = 1.651, 95% CI: 4.054–2.586, P = 0.029), married (vs. unmarried, OR = 0.593, 95%CI: 0.448–0.786, P < 0.001), and previously smoked (vs. never smoked, OR = 0.582, 95% CI: 0.342–0.990, P = 0.046) were significantly associated with practice scores. The multivariable logistic regression analysis revealed that the influencing factor for practice scores was only the knowledge scores (OR = 1.083, 95% CI: 1.042–1.127, P < 0.001) (Table 5).

sec.title: Mediation analysis
sec.p: The mediation analysis showed that knowledge was directly positively influenced by education (β = 1.37, P < 0.001) and income (β = 0.45, P < 0.001) but directly negatively influenced by smoking habit (β = − 0.51, P < 0.001) and pulmonary nodules (β = − 0.87, P = 0.002). Attitude was directly positively influenced by knowledge (β = 0.22, P < 0.001) and pulmonary nodules (β = 0.69, P = 0.036). The attitude was also indirectly positively influenced by education (β = 0.31, P < 0.001) and income (β = 0.10, P = 0.001) and indirectly negatively influenced by smoking habit (β = − 0.11, P < 0.001) and pulmonary nodules (β = − 0.19, P = 0.005). The practice was directly positively influenced by knowledge (β = 0.37, P < 0.001), education (β = 0.78, P = 0.012), and smoking habit (β = 0.46, P = 0.033). The practice was indirectly positively influenced by education (β = 0.46, P < 0.001) and income (β = 0.14, P = 0.003) and indirectly negatively influenced by smoking habit (β = − 0.16, P = 0.002) and pulmonary nodules (β = − 0.36, P = 0.002) (Fig. 1; Table 6). The fit of the model was good (Supplementary Table 1).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The present study investigated the KAP toward pulmonary nodules among Chinese adults. The results suggest that Chinese residents have poor knowledge and moderate attitudes and practices toward pulmonary nodules and that good knowledge may lead to better practices. Those results supported the original hypothesis that Chinese adults have a limited KAP toward pulmonary nodules. Therefore, public awareness of pulmonary nodules needs to be strengthened to improve the practice of the Chinese population.

These results indicated a significant deficit in participants’ knowledge related to pulmonary nodules. Consistent with our findings, it was reported that most patients had inadequate knowledge of pulmonary nodules and the nodules follow-up plan in the United States13,23,24.

With regard to the attitude dimension, more than 70% of the participants believed that pulmonary nodules were very common and benign with no need to worry or be followed up, which is supported by the SEM analysis showing a negative influence of pulmonary nodules on the attitude scores. Moreover, only about 34% of individuals explicitly stated that they would be anxious about being screened for pulmonary nodules. These results were inconsistent with previous studies, where many of the participants commonly assumed a pulmonary nodule was cancer and experienced different levels of distress12,25,26. This difference might be because the participants in our study were from the general population, whereas the participants in those previous studies were those with incidental pulmonary nodule detection. Interestingly, more than 40% of the participants were worried about CT radiation during screening or follow-up, which might have been influenced by the perception that radiological examinations are radioactive and should be avoided as much as possible. Considering the high costs and the fear of surgery, only about half of the participants were willing to accept PET-CT examinations or surgery if recommended by the doctors. This might have been attributed to the relatively low level of economic and social development, as well as the inadequate medical insurance system in China27,28. Although the relationship between smoking and pulmonary nodules remains to be studied, there has been validated evidence that smoking was associated with a significantly increased risk of lung cancer29,30. Therefore, quitting smoking may not necessarily reduce the detection rate of pulmonary nodules but can reduce the risk of malignant pulmonary nodules.

In addition, this study showed that there were significant differences in practice scores toward pulmonary nodules among sociodemographic factors. The lower scores were observed in the participants who were older than 40 years old, in high school/technical secondary school and below, and those with other marital statuses (e.g., divorced). Education and income had indirect positive influences on practice. This was similar to prior research investigating the association between sociodemographic factors and practice level towards disease prevention and management31–33. The knowledge scores were positively correlated with the practice score. These findings were consistent with evidence that knowledge can play a crucial role in enhancing the practice of public preventive behavior34–36. Although it is difficult to know the extent to which knowledge level would be sufficient for achieving desirable changes in health outcomes, the public can make more reasonable decisions based on sufficient knowledge of scientific evidence about relevant health issues37. Specifically, due to the phenomena of knowledge and practice inequality, more attention must be paid to those who showed lower knowledge and practice levels towards pulmonary nodules, such as individuals with old age, lower income level, and lower education level. The SEM showed that a smoking habit had a direct positive on practice but also an indirect negative influence on practice. It could denote the fact that the individuals are aware that smoking increases the risk of lung cancer but that they are also unwilling to give up smoking.

Although we considered multiple factors and tried to be comprehensive in the present study, there were still some limitations. Firstly, the results of the study were mainly based on self-reported materials, which might be prone to bias and/or overestimation of real results. Secondly, this study did not extensively explore other attitudinal factors associated with pulmonary nodule behaviors, such as communication factors that may influence the public’s knowledge, including seeking information, using the media, or processing information. Moreover, the questionnaire was self-designed, and its items differed from those of the previous studies; thus, there were difficulties in comparing the results of different studies. The study was cross-sectional, and causality could not be determined. Still, a SEM analysis was performed to estimate causality, but it must be remembered that such an estimate is a statistical estimation of causality based on predefined hypotheses20–22.

In conclusion, the findings of this study indicated that a significant population of adults in China had inadequate knowledge, attitude, and practice towards pulmonary nodules. Meanwhile, sufficient knowledge was associated with appropriate practices towards pulmonary nodules, suggesting that health education programs aimed at improving knowledge about pulmonary nodules may be helpful for encouraging appropriate attitudes and maintaining healthy practices.
